conclusion: Cart A is moving to the left with speed \(v_1\), Cart B is moving to the right with speed \(v_2\), and bullets are fired from Cart A with a speed \(v_0\) relative to the ground.
Bullets are fired every \(\Delta t_0\) time interval.
The relative speed between Cart A and Cart B is \(v_1 + v_2\).
The bullets travel at a constant speed \(v_0\) relative to the ground.
In the time \(\Delta t_0\), a bullet travels a distance \(S_1 = v_0 \cdot \Delta t_0\).
In the same time \(\Delta t_0\), Cart A moves a distance \(S_2 = v_1 \cdot \Delta t_0\) to the left.
The distance between two consecutive bullets in the air is the distance traveled by the first bullet minus the distance traveled by Cart A in the same time.
The distance \(s\) between two adjacent bullets is given by \(s = S_1 - S_2 = (v_0 \cdot \Delta t_0) - (v_1 \cdot \Delta t_0)\).
Simplifying, the distance between two adjacent bullets is \(s = (v_0 - v_1) \cdot \Delta t_0\).
The final answer is that the distance between two adjacent bullets in the air is \(s = (v_0 - v_1) \cdot \Delta t_0\).
